description.narrative: The new phase of DAPP (Danish-Arab Partnership Programme) 2017-2021 - focus on 4 prioritized countries Tunisia, Egypt, Jordan, Morocco. Committed to Youth, Innovation, DEDI, TAO, SNE, public diplomacy/communication, M&E + Reviews

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: Community-based sports activities as a platform for civic engagement

1.1 Capacity-building of youth to become leaders in community-based activities. 1.2 Engagement of youth as volunteers in community-based, meaningful activities. 1.3. Children, parents and other relevant community members are involved in meaningful activities creating integration and understanding across gender, social, ethnic and religious divides. 1.4. Engagement of local authorities, police and other relevant stakeholders in community-based, meaningful activities creating cooperation across sectors (expanded and consolidated in output 2 and 3).

target.value: #1 and 2. 1335 youth have gained a platform for volunteer work and civic engagement and have increased capacity to promote ideas of peaceful co-existence. gender equality and respect for human rights through meaningful and responsible work in their communities. 60 more of the youth have gained knowledge and capacity to lead and train others. #3. Children (9.000 in the OFFS alone) from various backgrounds have interacted and had fun with peers. have expanded their network of trustworthy role models and gained insights into values of peace. gender equality and respect for human rights. #4. Cross-sectorial partnerships are established to jointly carry out meaningful activities and tackle issues of children and youth showing signs of problematic behaviour (early detection).

#1 and #2. 870 youth have gained a platform for volunteer work and civic engagement and have increased capacity to promote ideas of peaceful co-existence. gender equality and respect for human rights through meaningful and responsible work in their communities. #3. Children (6.000 in the OFFS alone) from various backgrounds have interacted and had fun with peers. have expanded their network of trustworthy role models and gained insights into values of peace. gender equality and respect for human rights. #4. Cross-sectorial partnerships are established to jointly carry out meaningful activities.

actual.value: #1 and #2 555 youth have gained a platform for volenteer work. #3 Fulfilled

Children (3.000 in the OFFS alone) from various backgrounds have interacted and had fun with peers. have expanded their network of trustworthy role models and gained insights into values of peace. gender equality and respect for human rights. #4. Cross-sectorial partnerships have been initiated to jointly carry out meaningful activities.

Children (12.000 in the OFFS alone) from various backgrounds have interacted and had fun with peers. have expanded their network of trustworthy role models and gained insights into values of peace. gender equality. respect for human rights and cultural and social diversity. #4. Cross-sectorial partnerships are consolidated to jointly carry out meaningful activities and tackle issues of children and youth showing signs of problematic behaviour (early detection).

title.narrative: 2.1. Knowledge and capacity-building of 120 youth leaders in sports event management 2.2. The 120 youth leaders have gained planning and implementation skills in so-called big events (vs. smaller events such as OFFS) with a point of departure in the national HUB24, and used those events for public diplomacy purposes 2.3. Cross-sectorial SSP partnerships are formed and active across regional, national and local levels coordinated by a national SSP-coordinator based at the Ministry of Youth and Sports in each country 2.4. Engagement of the national network of young volunteers in the organisation of HUB24s in partnership with SSP-practitioners’ network 2.5. Minimum 9,600 youths have participated in the HUB24.

target.value: #2.1. 60 more youth leaders have gained skills and practical knowledge in sports event management and organised numerous small sports events and at least one big event (HUB24) in collaboration with local cross-sectorial partners and the experienced youth leaders. #2.2. The SSP-practitioners’ network has been further consolidated through monthly meetings and joint efforts in their communities. The national SSP-coordinators have received further training and passed on those lessons to their local SSP-partners to ensure progress and alignment.

#2.1. The youth leaders have gained skills and practical knowledge in sports event management and organised numerous small sport events and at least one big event (HUB24) in collaboration with local cross-sectorial partners and the experienced youth leaders. They have used the events as a platform for public diplomacy on some of the practical initiatives of DAPP. Their fundraising efforts have assured 50% coverage of the expenses for the annual HUB24. as well as for other activities. #2.2.1. One national SSP-coordinator is hired for each country and based at the Ministry of Youth and Sports (MOYS). They are trained in networking and capacity-building. #2.2.2. A network of SSP-practitioners across local. national and regional levels has been formed amongst the collaboration partners and has been trained in SSP-approaches to work with children and youth. The national SSP- coordinator has initiated a national dialogue and activities partnership.

actual.value: 2.1. Achieved. 2.2.1. Acieved. 2.2.2. The SSP approach has been adapted to Child Safegurading in Sports.

target.value: #2.1. 60 Youth leaders have gained skills and practical knowledge in sports event management and organised numerous small sports events and at least one big event (HUB24) in collaboration with 60 local cross-sectorial partners from the OFFS engagement. #2.2. Initial collaboration efforts and monthly meetings with the 60 cross-sectorial partners have been used to ensure the implementation of sports events and youth have gained knowledge on the benefits of using such networks.

#2.1. The youth leaders are now experienced sports event managers and plan and implement events beyond those proposed specifically by the project. They skill-fully use these events for public diplomacy purposes. Their fundraising efforts have assured 100% coverage of the expenses for the annual HUB24. as well as for other activities. #2.2. The SSP-practitioners’ network has been further consolidated through monthly meetings and joint efforts in their communities. The trust between the parties is now built so they can jointly tackle crime prevention and anti-radicalisation efforts amongst children and youth showing signs of problematic behaviours. The national SSP-coordinators have held workshops with their local SSP-partners to ensure progress and alignment across the nations and region.

title.narrative: Fundraising, sustainable structures and crime prevention/anti-radicalisation
Fundraising, sustainable structures and crime prevention/anti-radicalisation

target.value: #3.1. 100% of HUB24 is paid for by donations from national private and public enterprises. #3.2. The SSP-partnerships (youth leaders and cross-sectorial partners) are formally initiated on the basis of a strategic plan (CCPA seminar manual) and dialogue meetings are held throughout the year.

#3.1. 60 youth leaders and 240 cross-sectorial partners have been trained and gained capacity to facilitate self-organisation. including fundraising skills. and co-creation of consolidated cross-sectorial partnerships. They report the benefits from opportunities offered by a consolidated and cross-sectorial network. 3.1.1 50% of HUB24 is paid for by donations from national private and public enterprises #3.2. The SSP-partnerships (youth leaders and cross-sectorial partners) are formally initiated on the basis of a strategic plan (CCPA seminar manual) and dialogue meetings are held throughout the year.

actual.value: 3.1. Achieved. 3.2. Support does not amoun to 50%. 3.3. The SSP approach has succesfully been adatped to a Child Safeguaridng Sports Approach.

title.narrative: The youth have built capacity to carry out volunteer work enhancing interaction and understanding between children and youth of different backgrounds and genders, and gained a platform to voice their visions for society. The youth work within a sustainable structure of youth sports networks and cross sectorial-networks with capacity to work and fundraise for a peaceful co-existence, including crime prevention and anti-radicalisation.

target.value: 1. A platform for youth’s engagement in civil society work and for voicing their vision for society has been formed and implemented. 2. CCPA’s SSP-approach builds a bridge between the youth and stakeholders across relevant sectors. which will increase trust between the parties so that they can jointly work to prevent criminalisation and radicalisation. The focus is particularly on early detection mechanisms. 3. The youth will be engaged in meaningful and potentially income-generating work through sports and become part of a greater network providing for stronger resilience and social cohesion. As role models they gain responsibility. which is of vital importance in resilience. They will work to prevent crime and radicalisation rather than become part of it.

title.narrative: Knowledge collection on sports-based NGO work

1. Overview of sports-based NGOs’ activities in the MENA-region and the various approaches they use in their work. 2. Specific issues addressed in four lessons learned reports based on study tours and joint seminars amongst sports-based NGOs, led by CCPA in consultation with GAME and street football world: 1.1 Report on different approaches to the use of sport as a platform for volunteerism and strengthening of civil society. 1.2 Report focusing on gender issues and dynamics when working with sports-based approaches to humanitarian work. 1.3 Report focusing on the different approaches, dynamics and outcomes in rural and urban settings. 1.4 Report on the possibilities for sports-based humanitarian work in crime prevention and anti-radicalisation.

target.value: A knowledge-base is created focusing on the different approaches. specifically addressing vital issues to ensure quality and continued progression of sports-based humanitarian work.

Quite a lot of humanitarian work is done in the MENA-region using sport as a mobiliser and entry point. but there is no coordination. transparency and only little collaboration amongst the actors. There is a need for a knowledge-base on how to use sports as a mobiliser and how it contributes to various aspects of the work. as well as an overview of the various projects and approaches.
